element.short: Item containing charge code(s) associated with the provision of healthcare provider products
element.definition: The resource ChargeItem describes the provision of healthcare provider products for a certain patient, therefore referring not only to the product, but containing in addition details of the provision, like date, time, amounts and participating organizations and persons. Main Usage of the ChargeItem is to enable the billing process and internal cost allocation.

If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.short: Defining information about the code of this charge item
element.definition: References the source of pricing information, rules of application for the code this ChargeItem uses.
element.comment: Target Resource is yet to be defined as a container that holds information about list prices and rules applicable to the charge item code. Once defined, change type back to Reference(Definition Type).

element.short: planned | billable | not-billable | aborted | billed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The current state of the ChargeItem.
element.comment:
Unknown does not represent "other" - one of the defined statuses must apply.  Unknown is used when the authoring system is not sure what the current status is.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the charge item as not currently valid.

element.definition: Describes the type of performance or participation(e.g. primary surgeon, anaesthesiologiest, etc.).

binding.description: Codes describing the types of functional roles performers can take on when performing events

element.definition: The device, practitioner, etc. who performed or participated in the service.
The organization requesting the service.
element.comment: Practitioners and Devices can be associated with multiple organizations. It has to be made clear, on behalf of which Organization the services have been rendered.

element.definition: The organization performing the service.
element.comment: The rendered Service may not be associated with a Request. It has to be made clear, ob which Organization's Request, the services have been rendered. (In many cases, this may just be the Department associated with the Encounter.location).

element.short: Quantity of which the charge item has been serviced
element.definition: Quantity of which the charge item has been serviced.
element.comment: In many cases this may just be a value, if the underlying units are implicit in the definition of the charge item code.

element.definition: The anatomical location where the related service has been applied.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in Condition.code. If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [body-site-instance](extension-body-site-instance.html).  May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.definition: Factor overriding the factor determined by the rules associated with the code.
element.comment: There is no reason to carry the factor in the instance of a ChargeItem unless special circumstances require a manual override. The factors are usually defined by a set of rules in a back catalogue of the billing codes  (see ChargeItem.definition). Derived profiles may require a ChargeItem.overrideReason to be provided if either factor or price are manually overriden.

element.definition: Total price of the charge overriding the list price associated with the code.
element.comment: There is no reason to carry the price in the instance of a ChargeItem unless circumstances require a manual override. The list prices or are usually defined in a back catalogue of the billing codes  (see ChargeItem.definition). Derived profiles may require a ChargeItem.overrideReason to be provided if either factor or price are manually overriden.

element.short: Reason for overriding the list price/factor
element.definition: If the list price or the rule based factor associated with the code is overridden, this attribute can capture a text to indicate the  reason for this action.
element.comment: Derived Profiles may chose to add invariants requiring this field to be populated if either priceOverride or factorOverride have been filled.

element.definition: The device, practitioner, etc. who entered the charge item.
element.comment: The enterer is also te person considered responsible for factor/priceOverrides if applicable.

element.short: Date the charge item was entered
element.definition: Date the charge item was entered.
element.comment: The actual date when the service associated with the charge has been rendered is captured in occurrence[x].

element.short: Why was the charged  service rendered?
element.definition: Describes why the event occurred in coded or textual form.
element.comment: If the application of the charge item requires a reason to be given, it can be captured here. Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

element.short: Which rendered service is being charged?
element.definition: Indicated the rendered service that caused this charge.
Account into which this ChargeItems belongs.
element.comment: Systems posting the ChargeItems may not always be able to determine, which accounts the Items need to be places into. It is up to the potprocessing Financial System to apply internal rules to decide based on the Encounter/EpisodeOfCare/Patient/Coverage context and the type of ChargeItem, which Account is appropriate.
